in this industry up until recently there wasn't much and now it's starting to become more and more

they Define uh proprietary layouts of the data on the
bus and they assume that people won't find out what it is and this held true basically from when was new back in 1989

sec.org you can still find those and they're actually great research to uh get your feet wet with automotive

used only the vehicle identification number or vin to authenticate and allow
the remote control now a VIN number is something that's actually stamped on the front of a car and there's actually

the vehicle so clearly that's not a very good authentication token and so this broke down as well so once we you know
have these IP uh things show up where people people are very used to dealing with these protocols it breaks down
pretty quickly whereas when you look at Can 1989 to 2010 there wasn't too much work done on
it so the first thing you do here and I apologize for those that are automotive folks because I think it's important to
do sort of an introduction to can and Automotive networking so we'll do this kind of quick but can is controller area
network it's been around since 1989 when Bosch first created the uh the first controllers and
transceivers the reason you see this in the automotive world is that there's lowcost and highly integrated
controllers so not only are the can controllers quite cheap they're actually
built into the microcontrollers and these are controllers that meet the required certifications to be used in
automotive devices we need devices that are going to be able to do deal with
temperature ranges vibration uh temperature cycling humidity and there actually are qualifications the main one
is aec Q100 that part doesn't have that qualification you won't really see it in
the car and it just so happens that because can has been used in automotive it's very easy to get parts that have
this qualification and that have built-in can controllers also there's history everyone uses it there's tools
out there people are very aware of how it works in the automotive world so there are a number of types of can the
main one we'll be talking about is differential or highp speed can this is what you see really between most vehicle
controllers that are of importance to vehicle safety and vehicle operation there also is a low-speed can
bus and this is used more for convenience features things like Windows lights doors things that are not as
critical to the safety of the vehicle it's cheaper to run one wire instead of two so instead of running a differential
signal they just run one wire in ground which is the chassis of the vehicle and you can reduce your costs of the
transceiver of the connectors and of the wiring harnesses fault tolerant can is
something you see in more in the airbag World it actually has the ability to
operate as differential can but in the event that one of the two wires gets cut for some reason it becomes a single wire
can bus so you end up with some tolerance to faults like you know braking wires and finally we have can FD
which is a newer uh technology it actually gets over some of the limitations of can it's starting to be
adopted and we'll talk a little bit more about that later but a typical can bus that you look at is going to have a
collection of controllers that are all sitting on a bus now it's important to note here there is no switch like an
Ethernet Network they are all just connected up to up to that bus so everyone has the ability to control the
bus in any time and using an arbitration technique they actually manage to decide
who should talk when and in a lot of systems now you see gateways this is sort of a naive really simple fits on a
slide diagram real Automotive architectures are quite a bit more detailed and complex and are also
typically proprietary so I can't put them on a slide but uh this has a BCM or
a body control module acting as a Gateway between two buses so it will let
you get messages or get data from one bus onto another example here you might
have an engine control module that's generating an RPM value this instrument panel which is on this other low speeed
or single wire can bus it needs the RPM value to properly display your Tac so
the BCM is going to receive that information wrap it up into a new can frame and transmit it maybe at a
different rate maybe in a different way but it will it'll be transmitting that message so we're going to look at sort
of the software model of how can works I'm not going to get too much into the electrical details of can just because
it's not terribly relevant for this topic it's a bit out of scope for this
but whenever you're looking at it as a software person you have a can bus and this is a collection of controllers that
are all networked on this single bus it was the red and green lines in the previous picture on the bus you're going
to have frames and a frame is a single sort of can packet it's it's an atomic
thing that contains three main uh items there's an identifier and that tells you
what is the message so what's going to be inside of it there's a data length code which simply says how many bytes
are it in this message it's 0 to8 can only supports payloads of up to eight
bytes and there's the data part which is your 0 to 8 bytes of data and really
that's it it's quite simple that's all a canf frame is and later we'll see can frames and that's all that's inside if
you look at the electrical stuff there's some crc's that happen and there's some acknowledgement that actually allows
these things to be quite reliable in practice but if you're developing for can this is really what you're looking
at so there's two main ways that can is used in vehicles and the first one is
the signal databases if you work in the automotive industry I'm talking about DBC files is typically what these are
represented as and this is a rather simple example of how this works but this is how when your vehicle is running
normally in just day-to-day operation almost all of the communication happens
this way and this example we have a can frame and it's leaving the engine
control module it's being picked up by an instrument cluster now I have marked out that these are the controllers here
in real life if you are connected to the bus you don't actually know who is sending a frame and you don't know who's
receiving it it's just being published it's a totally broadcast system but for this example we have the engine control
module instrument cluster we have an ID of ox123 and then some some data now
when you first connect to a canvas you're going to see data flying around a lot of these all over the place and
what's actually happening in your vehicle is decoding so it's quite simple
the bytes of this message will have meaning which is predefined at the time
where the vehicle software was designed so in this case these first two bytes might be an engine
RPM uh I actually saw a Ken buus just the other day that it was in fact a
message not that ID but it was the first two bytes for an engine RPM just direct correlation so this ox5 DC you know it's
a 2 by long message you can then take that value conver it to engineering units and you get something like 1500
RPM the goal of a signal database or the purpose of a signal database is to tell you what the IDS mean what's contained
in these uh eight bytes because it might be engine RPM vehicle speed uh is it
raining one bit of the rain light sensor uh headlight status sunroof status all
these things are being broadcast all the time so the database tells you what's in there and also how convert from just
these raw bites on the bus to actual engineering units which is really useful whenever you actually want to get real
data out of a vehicle it's not so useful to know that it's ox1 1234 you want to know that that means that uh your high
voltage battery in an electric vehicle is at you know 63.2 7% state of charge
so those those conversions are done by these signal databases they're all
defined at the time where you design the system and then the software that's actually running on the controllers has
this statically set up there's another way that can is used and this is not a datay thing but it's
definitely true of any vehicle you have absolutely any vehicle that's passed uh was made past 1991 is going to have some
form of Diagnostics it was first mandated solely for emissions purposes by the California air resources board
who actually have led a lot of innovation in automotive and they wanted to be able to get data on vehicles for
the purpose of being able to do smog tests because in order to you know look at the
emissions of a vehicle know what the vehicle's running and actually be able to tell what the emissions were you need
certain information on you know air flow fuel flow things like that so they came up with this OBD which is really a
readon protocol it's the only thing you can really write with OBD is you can clear fault codes but you can read out
what are called pids or parameter IDs for all sorts of stuff you can get vehicle speed engine RPM airflow values
uh you can get like temperature sensing uh all kinds of information it's all standardized there's a great Wikipedia
article that has every pit it's basically the like number one reference online for that
information but OBD that's the limit you can get fault codes clear fault codes that's it now manufacturers they needed
to be able to do more than that for things like setting up vehicle VIN numbers or reflashing vehicle firmware
and there's a number of approaches for this between you know when this all started up until around 2008 around 2008
everyone started to standardize on unified diagnostic services or UDS and
UDS is a Diagnostics uh implementation it's an application Level
implementation that uh provides different services for everything from updating firmware to writing arbitrary
memory if you wish to implement that and it's based on a challenge or sorry a
request response Paradigm so you send a request out to an automotive controller and most Automotive controllers in a
vehicle will have this implemented asking for read read this identifier
which might be some arbitrary data uh I want to do a firmware update I want to read a particular memory address I want
to reset this ECU there's about uh 20 or 30 of the different services that you can actually pull off and that
controller it's going to determine if it's happy if it's going to let you do the thing that you requested and if so
it's going to send you back response so you typically see this as a scan tool which is what a mechanic is going to be
using plugged into your vehicle over the OBD port in the car it's going to send
out a request that server which is the actual controller generates a response and sends it back and you can chain
these together to create sessions and there's different ways of implementing security for the sessions and all that
but this is the other common application of Canan other than just signal
databases so if you want to do this stuff you're going to need some tools because MacBooks and lovos or whatever
you have on your lap those don't do can they they do ethernet they do USB there are no can devices built in there's a
lot of different tools out there and almost all of them are expensive so Vector is sort of like the
the gold Stander in the industry they make very complex tools that are used for all sorts of stuff and are almost

typically five figures plus these are in US dollars uh kavasa is another company they make

signal databases really what you're looking to do is watch a bunch of messages all at once change stuff and

we got in a car we waited for a GPS fix we drove it as North as we could and we
we watched all the messages changing and and sure enough you have something that's updating about once a second
which is makes sense for GPS and also you know it's split into two 32-bit uh
segments and you have the uh first 32-bit segment that's updating quite quickly and the second one isn't

that's how a lot of this happens you kind of fiddle with the system and you look at what's going on and you get that

what changes is the data and as that data changes and this is a simple example it gets highlighted in red which

open the sunroof change your position for GPS and whatever is turning red is
what's changing it sounds like a really simple method of doing this it sounds almost too simple uh when you explain it

bytes but if you want to read something like a vid number which is around 20

it's sort of an interchangeable name and it's just a standard for saying you know I have up to 4,95 bytes I would like to

on the frames in order to say this is the first frame and we're going to send use this many and send that payload and

90 is 144 and it's coming back with a hey here's that data identifier so this

Diagnostics tool this is showing a single view of it but it basically has a

and you hit send key and it sends that over uh and historically the as I said
